name: acetamide, n-acetyl-2-(benzoyloxy)-
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for comparison can be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of acetamide, n-acetyl-2-(benzoyloxy)-, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
